--- title: "Aesthetics" format: html: toc: false section-divs: true include-after-body: - text: | engine: knitr filters: - webr webr: packages: - ggplot2 - dplyr cell-options: editor-font-scale: 0.85 fig-width: 6 fig-height: 3.7 out-width: "70%" --- ### Aesthetics for bars {.no-hide} `geom_bar()` and `geom_col()` can use several aesthetics: * `alpha` * `color` * `fill` * `linetype` * `size` One of these, `color`, creates the most surprising results. Predict what the code below will return and then run it. ::: {.panel-tabset} ## {{< fa code >}} Interactive editor ```{webr-r} ggplot( data = diamonds, mapping = aes(x = cut, color = cut) ) + geom_bar() ``` ::: ### `fill` The `color` aesthetic controls the outline of each bar in your bar plot, which may not be what you want. To color the interior of each bar, use the `fill` aesthetic: ::: {.cell layout-ncol="2" layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](05-aesthetics_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){fig-align='center' width=100%} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](05-aesthetics_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-2-2.png){fig-align='center' width=100%} ::: ::: Use the code chunk below to experiment with fill, along with other `geom_bar()` aesthetics, like `alpha`, `linetype`, and `size`. ::: {.panel-tabset} ## {{< fa code >}} Interactive editor ```{webr-r} ggplot( data = diamonds, mapping = aes(x = cut, color = cut) ) + geom_bar() ``` ::: ### Width You can control the width of each bar in your bar chart with the `width` parameter. In the chunk below, set `width = 1`, then `width = 0.5`. Can you spot the difference? ::: {.panel-tabset} ## {{< fa code >}} Interactive editor ```{webr-r} ggplot( data = diamonds, mapping = aes(x = cut, fill = cut) ) + geom_bar(width = 0.9) ``` ::: Notice that width is a _parameter_, not an aesthetic mapping. Hence, you should set width _outside_ of the `aes()` function. ### Exercise 5: Aesthetics Create a colored bar chart of the `class` variable from the `mpg` data set, which comes with ggplot2. Map the interior color of each bar to `class`. ::: {.panel-tabset} ## {{< fa code >}} Interactive editor ```{webr-r} ``` ## {{< fa circle-check >}} Solution ```r ggplot( data = mpg, mapping = aes(x = class, fill = class) ) + geom_bar() ``` ::: ## ::: {.cell layout-align="center"}
